thread.title: Maher Reviews His First 100-Days As Superintendent
thread.title_full: Maher Reviews His First 100-Days As Superintendent

title: Maher Reviews His First 100-Days As Superintendent
text:
Maher Reviews His First 100-Days As Superintendent October 8, 2015, 5:05 PM by Leland Steva SIOUX FALLS, SD - 
It's a milestone for Sioux Falls Superintendent Brian Maher. He's now been the leader of the largest school district in South Dakota for 100 days. 
Maher took over the position on July 1st, after being the Superintendent in Kearney Nebraska since 2007. He oversees 3,500 employees, 450 of them new to the district, as well as more than 23,000 students. 
"Gosh it feels like day 5 or 10. It has just flown by," Brian Maher said. 
In a short amount of time, Brian Maher has made a big impression. After being in Sioux Falls for 100 days, he knows he made the right decision. 
"Personally for me, the right fit. This is a good job for me I like that on a personal level. On a professional level there's a lot of tremendous things that happen in the school system in Sioux Falls," Maher said. 
Maher had a 100-day plan in place when he came to KELOLAND. It was to get to know people across the state. He's been able to do that as he joined the Blue Ribbon Task Force. The group, made up of lawmakers, teachers, and administrators across the state, has allowed Maher to communicate with a wide variety of people. 
Under his leadership, substitute teachers in Sioux Falls got an increase in pay by 10 percent. Maher's work has impressed the school board as well. 
"You hope that what you hear and what you read is true but when he exceeds your expectations that's been a real exciting part. And to hear the feedback from the community and just the experience first-hand has just been awesome," School Board Member Todd Thoelke said. 
As he works on improving Sioux Falls schools while building up relationships statewide. Maher has a lot on his plate, but it's a challenge he enjoys. 
"I feel like I'm plenty busy. I don't think I'm stretched out too thin. I feel like it's the job that I signed up for," Maher said. Â© 2015 KELOLAND TV. All Rights Reserved.
